overview: The purpose and intent of this measure is to require pharmacy technicians to be registered with and obtain a certificate of registration from the Board of Pharmacy, beginning January 1, 2026. [12] The bill imposes a duty on pharmacists-in-charge to report violations conducted by registered pharmacy technicians. [12] It also specifies that supervising registered pharmacists are responsible for the actions of registered pharmacy technicians and pharmacy interns. [12]
appropriations: The provided legislative documents do not contain any specific appropriations for this measure. [11] However, the bill specifies that the registration fee for a pharmacy technician shall be $20.00 (HB72_SD1_.HTM.txt). [CHUNK_72, NUMBER_0] Testimony indicates that this initiative comes at a reasonable cost and represents a prudent investment. [10]
assumptions_and_methodology: The fiscal analysis is based on the specific fees and fines established in the bill text. [11] [11] The measure establishes a registration fee of $20.00 (HB72_SD1_.HTM.txt) for pharmacy technicians, which will generate revenue. [CHUNK_72, NUMBER_0] The provided documents do not contain quantitative projections on the number of pharmacy technicians in Hawai'i, making a total revenue estimate difficult. [10]
agency_impact: The Board of Pharmacy will be required to issue certificates of registration for registered pharmacy technicians. [11] The Board may fine, suspend, or revoke any registration for any cause prescribed by this chapter. [11] The Board voted unanimously to support this measure and has already formed a permitted interaction group to look at the best methods to regulate pharmacy technicians. [10] [10]
economic_impact: Hawaiʻi is the only state that does not maintain a list of practicing pharmacy technicians, and this measure aligns Hawaiʻi with national best practices. [10] [10] This important measure will bring a regulatory framework to the critical role that pharmacy technicians fill. [10] Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined no less than $100.00 (HB72_SD1_.HTM.txt) and no more than $1,000.00 (HB72_SD1_.HTM.txt) for each violation. [CHUNK_125, CHUNK_126, NUMBER_1, NUMBER_2]
policy_impact: This measure builds upon Act 104 of the 2024 legislative session that allows pharmacy technicians the ability to administer immunizations and vaccinations. [10] [10] Your Committee has amended this measure by deleting language that would have required the supervision to be "direct" and deleting language that would have required the pharmacist to be physically present. [12] [12] The bill also specifies that Section 26H-6, Hawaii Revised Statutes, which relates to sunrise analysis requirements, shall not apply to this Act. [11]
revenue_sources: The bill establishes a new revenue source through a registration fee for pharmacy technicians. [11] The registration fee for a pharmacy technician shall be $20.00 (HB72_SD1_.HTM.txt). [CHUNK_72, NUMBER_0] Additional revenue may be generated from fines for violations, which shall be no less than $100.00 (HB72_SD1_.HTM.txt) and no more than $1,000.00 (HB72_SD1_.HTM.txt) for each violation. [CHUNK_125, CHUNK_126, NUMBER_1, NUMBER_2]
six_year_fiscal_implications: The provided documents do not contain a six-year fiscal projection. [12] A new revenue stream will be created from registration fees. [11] The registration fee for a pharmacy technician shall be $20.00 (HB72_SD1_.HTM.txt). [CHUNK_72, NUMBER_0] Each certificate of registration shall be valid through December 31 of each odd-numbered year, upon which a new registration shall be required, suggesting a biennial renewal process. [11] Without a formal registry, there is little visibility into the number of technicians working in the state, making precise revenue projections difficult. [10] The Board of Pharmacy may also impose fines between $100.00 (HB72_SD1_.HTM.txt) and $1,000.00 (HB72_SD1_.HTM.txt) for each violation. [CHUNK_126, NUMBER_1, NUMBER_2] The creation of a pharmacy technician data repository is an essential step forward, but any associated administrative costs are not specified. [10] Testimony describes the measure as a prudent investment in the safety, efficiency, and adaptability of the pharmacy workforce. [10] This bill is a crucial step toward strengthening Hawai'i’s healthcare infrastructure. [10] The Board agreed that a registration for all technicians may be a prudent initial step regarding the regulation of pharmacy technicians. [10]
operating_revenue_impact: This measure will generate new operating revenue for the state. [11] A registration fee of $20.00 (HB72_SD1_.HTM.txt) will be collected from each pharmacy technician on a biennial basis. [CHUNK_72, CHUNK_71, NUMBER_0] Additional, though less predictable, revenue may be generated from fines for violations, which can range from $100.00 (HB72_SD1_.HTM.txt) to $1,000.00 (HB72_SD1_.HTM.txt). capital_expenditure_impact: The provided legislative documents do not indicate any capital expenditures are required for this measure. [11] [12] No investments in facilities, equipment, or technology are mentioned in the bill text or supporting testimonies. [11] [10] The purpose and intent of this measure is to establish a regulatory system, not to fund capital projects. [12]
fiscal_implications_after_6_years: The ongoing fiscal impact of this measure will be the recurring revenue from the biennial renewal of pharmacy technician registrations. [11] The registration fee is established at $20.00 (HB72_SD1_.HTM.txt). [CHUNK_72, NUMBER_0] Because Hawai'i currently lacks a managed list of practicing pharmacy technicians, the total number of registrants and long-term revenue potential is unknown. [10]
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: This fiscal note is based on H.B. No. 72, S.D. 1, which contains significant changes from prior versions. [12] The bill now establishes a specific registration fee for a pharmacy technician of $20.00 (HB72_SD1_.HTM.txt), creating a defined revenue source. [CHUNK_72, NUMBER_0] It also introduces fines for violations of no less than $100.00 (HB72_SD1_.HTM.txt) and no more than $1,000.00 (HB72_SD1_.HTM.txt). [CHUNK_125, CHUNK_126, NUMBER_1, NUMBER_2] The Committee on Health and Human Services amended the measure by deleting language requiring supervision to be "direct" and removing the requirement for a pharmacist to be "physically present". [12] [12] A new effective date of December 31, 2050 has been inserted to encourage further discussion, resolving the defective date in the previous version. [12] [11]
fte_positions: The provided legislative documents and testimonies do not specify the addition or modification of any Full Time Equivalent (FTE) positions. [11] [12] There is no mention of new staffing being required to implement or manage the registration program. [12] The bill's focus is on establishing the regulatory requirements for pharmacy technicians. [12]
appropriations_changes: No appropriations were specified in the previous version, and no new appropriations are included in H.B. No. 72, S.D. 1. [11] This version of the bill establishes a funding mechanism through the creation of a registration fee. [11] The registration fee for a pharmacy technician shall be $20.00 (HB72_SD1_.HTM.txt). [CHUNK_72, NUMBER_0]
funding_sources_changes: This version of the bill establishes a specific funding source through registration fees, which was not defined in previous versions. [11] The bill states that the registration fee for a pharmacy technician shall be $20.00 (HB72_SD1_.HTM.txt). [CHUNK_72, NUMBER_0] The documents do not specify whether these fees will be deposited into the general fund or a special fund for the Board of Pharmacy. [11]
department_impact: The department impacted by this measure remains the Department of Commerce and Consumer Affairs, under which the Board of Pharmacy operates. [11] [10] There is no change in the responsible department from previous versions of the bill. [12] The Board of Pharmacy has confirmed its support for the measure's intent to regulate pharmacy technicians. [10]
reports_required: The reporting requirements in this version of the bill are unchanged. [12] If a registered pharmacy technician is suspected to have violated any law or rule, the pharmacist-in-charge shall notify the board, in writing, within ten days. [11] Any registered pharmacist who has knowledge or suspicion of another registered pharmacy technician in violation of any law or rule shall also notify the board. [11]
pilot_program: This measure does not create a pilot program. [11] It establishes a permanent registration requirement for pharmacy technicians beginning January 1, 2026. [11] The bill is intended to align Hawai'i with national pharmacy technician regulation standards on a permanent basis. [10]
sunset_date: The Committee on Health and Human Services amended the measure by inserting an effective date of December 31, 2050. [12] This date was inserted to encourage further discussion and is not a traditional sunset clause. [12]
effective_date: An effective date, which was previously defective, has been specified in this version of the bill. [12] This Act shall take effect on December 31, 2050. [11]
